Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How do phage drive bacterial diversity in Lake Michigan near-shore waters? A bioinformatics perspective
Award.AbstractNarration:
Loyola University of Chicago is awarded a grant to establish a multidisciplinary team for the development and application of new tools for the synthesis of next-generation viral metagenomic sequence data. With the advent of next-generation sequencing (NGS) instrumentation, the throughput and cost-effectiveness of studying entire complex environmental communities is now feasible. A critical member of many ecological niches, the viral species which infect bacteria (phage) play an important role in maintaining the bacterial diversity within the community as well as nutrient cycling. Despite advances in sequencing technology, identifying and/or classifying the viruses present in a particular habitat is a significant challenge as relatively little genomic data is available for this the most abundant species on earth. Classifying novel species will be achieved by fusing existing and new tools, integrating our knowledge of viral biosynthetic compatibility with their host. This will be conducted in concert with a long-term study of the viral diversity present within Loyola University Chicago's own backyard - the near-shore waters of Lake Michigan. Utilizing novel computational methods, this research will ascertain if and how phage are shaping the bacterial diversity and density in this environment. The tools developed and data generated, both of which will be made freely available, will benefit future studies of environmental viriomes.

This project has broad impacts, including the continuation of several ongoing initiatives for the instruction of minorities and women in multidisciplinary science. Furthermore, it will bring together undergraduate students in computational and biological sciences to do research both in the laboratory as well as in the classroom. Through the development of new courses and integration into existing courses, students will be engaged in and drive active investigation within the classroom. For instance, students drawn to the more computational aspects would be engaged in a unique experience in the laboratory and classroom, contributing to the development of a large project, directly applying concepts of data structure and algorithm design. The nature of this study will be of interest to a large number of students at Loyola University Chicago, providing students with a greater understanding of the environment in which they live as well as exposing the next generation of scientists to interdisciplinary approaches in research. For more information about the project visit the PI's lab website at http://sites.google.com/site/putonti/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Genomic analyses of complex environmental communities are now feasible with modern sequencing technologies. While much focus is often placed on the cellular members of these communities, viruses play a vital role. Bacteria-infecting viruses (bacteriophages) mediate global biogeochemical processes and drive microbial evolution within these communities. Despite their importance, very little is known about the diversity and structure of phage communities. The project led to the development of several bioinformatic tools specifically aimed at the identification and characterization of single phage species as well as complex phage communities. These tools are all publicly available and free to use. While developed to specifically look at phages within freshwater environments, they can be used for the investigation of phages in any environment. In parallel, the project produced the first comprehensive evaluation of viral and bacterial species within Chicago’s near-shore waters of Lake Michigan. Phage and bacteria were surveyed regularly over several years and at several sites. All sequencing data generated by this study are publicly available through NCBI. Novel phage species were also isolated and characterized as part of our study, thus increasing our understanding of the role of phages in maintaining and structuring the native bacteria within these waters. This work lays the foundation for subsequent studies in the role of microbial communities in maintaining the health of Lake Michigan.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has broad impacts, including the continuation of several ongoing initiatives for the instruction of minorities and women in multidisciplinary science. Undergraduates were a vital part of the project, bringing together students in computational and biological sciences to do research. Seven undergraduates were directly supported through summer research fellowships created as part of this project. Undergraduate and Master’s student trainees presented their work at 14 area, national, and international conferences and are authors on manuscripts. This project also led to the creation of a new course at Loyola University Chicago, Metagenomics, which trained undergraduate and Master’s students in the classroom in the latest bioinformatic tools for the study of sequencing data from complex microbial communities. These students represented majors in biology, statistics, physics, and computer science. Collaboratively, the students prepared manuscripts presenting their results; one of the students’ papers has been published to date. Teaching resources are under development for public distribution so that other institutions can implement similar courses. The project has also provided students and Chicagoans with a greater understanding of the environment in which they live, increasing awareness of the importance of microbial communities in nature.
